name: Phonemic discrimination (native)
full_citation: Tsuji, S. & Cristia, A. (2013). Perceptual attunement in vowels: A meta-analysis. Developmental Psychobiology, 56(2), 179-191.
description: Discrimination of vowels, including results from behavioral, electrophysiological, and neuroimaging methods applied to infants 0-14 months of age.

name: Phonemic discrimination (non-native)
full_citation: Tsuji, S. & Cristia, A. (2013). Perceptual attunement in vowels: A meta-analysis. Developmental Psychobiology, 56(2), 179-191.
description: Discrimination of vowels, including results from behavioral, electrophysiological, and neuroimaging methods applied to infants 0-14 months of age.

name: Word segmentation
full_citation: Bergmann, C., & Cristia, A. (in press). Development of infantsâ€™ segmentation of words from native speech: A meta-analytic approach. Developmental Science.
description: Recognition of familiarized words from running, natural speech using behavioral methods applied to infants 0-20 months of age.

name: Infant directed speech preference
full_citation: Dunst, C. J., Gorman, E., & Hamby, D. W. (2012). Preference for infant-directed speech in preverbal young children. Center for Early Literacy Learning, 5(1).
description: Looking times as a function of whether infant-directed vs. adult-directed speech is presented as stimulation, in infants aged 0-XX months.

name: Mutual exclusivity
full_citation: Lewis, M. & Frank, M. (in preparation). Mutual exclusivity: A meta-analysis.
description: Mutual exclusivity is the bias for children to assume a novel word refers to a novel object, in the presence of one novel and one familiar object. This meta-analysis covers behavioral experiments on infants aged XX to XX.

name: Label advantage in concept learning
description: Previous research suggests that labels support the formation of novel categories in young children. This meta-analysis includes studies exploring this question that use a paradigm similar to Balaban and Waxman (1997), resulting in a selection of experiments using behavioral methods on infants XX to XX months.

name: Phonotactic learning in the lab
full_citation: Cristia, A. (in preparation). Infants' phonology learning in the lab.
description: Laboratory experiments in which infants are exposed to a set of pseudo-words that could support a phonotactic generalization, and thereafter tested on their preference between new types that follow or violate the familiarized phonotactics.

name: Sound learning in the lab from acoustic cue distributions
full_citation: Cristia, A. (in preparation). Infants' phonology learning in the lab.
description: Laboratory experiments in which infants are exposed to a set of syllables that have been generated using a bimodal distribution of acoustic cues or not, and infants are tested on their discrimination of two sounds differing along the same dimension.

name: Individual variation in infant speech perception tasks
full_citation: Cristia, A., Seidl, A., Junge, C., Soderstrom, M., & Hagoort, P. (2014) Infant predictors of language. Child Development, 85(4), 1330-1345.
description: Correlations between infant (4-12 months) performance in a speech perception task that is plausibly affected by language experience, on the one hand, and vocabulary, on the other, concurrently and/or longitudinally. Also contains some data points from infant processing of non-speech stimuli.
